title: 103_hr103
content:
The "Fair and Competitive Election Act" is the short title of the legislation. It includes a limitation on contributions to House of Representatives elections from individuals who are not local residents. The "Fair and Competitive Election Act" limits contributions to House of Representatives elections from non-local residents. Candidates exceeding the contribution limit must refund or pay penalties. The "Fair and Competitive Election Act" imposes penalties on candidates who accept contributions exceeding the limit by 10 percent or more, requiring them to pay three times the excess contributions to the Commission. Additionally, an individual cannot be considered a resident of more than one congressional district for the purpose of this subsection. SEC. 3. REDUCTION IN LIMITATION AMOUNT FOR NONPARTY MULTICANDIDATE POLITICAL COMMITTEE CONTRIBUTIONS TO CANDIDATES. No nonparty multicandidate political committee may contribute more than $1,000 in aggregate. Technical amendment made to Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971.

SEC. 4. BAN ON SOFT MONEY. Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 amended to include limitations and reporting requirements for amounts paid for mixed political activities. Sec. 323 imposes limitations and reporting requirements on payments for mixed political activities by national or state political party committees. The term 'mixed political activity' refers to activities that aim to influence federal elections and have purposes unrelated to such influence. Additionally, Section 301(8)(B) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to remove the building fund exception from the definition of 'contribution'. Transition rule regarding excess funds of House of Representatives candidates. A candidate running for Congress with campaign accounts exceeding the contribution limit must deposit the excess funds into a separate account. These excess funds can be used for any lawful purpose except for the candidate's election campaign. The excess funds are those exceeding twice the amount raised from local individual residents after December 31, 1992. Candidates can transfer excess funds back to the campaign account if the majority of funds were raised locally. No funds can be transferred from the separate account to a campaign account. Candidates with campaign accounts exceeding the contribution limit must deposit excess funds into a separate account. These funds can be used for any lawful purpose except for the candidate's election campaign. Excess funds are those exceeding twice the amount raised from local individual residents after December 31, 1992. No transfers are allowed from a separate account to a campaign account after the 1994 pre-primary report period. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment.
